Stability of Mo2C/carbon catalysts during dibenzofuran hydrodeoxygenation Shida Liu a Haiyan Wang a Chang Soo Kim b * Kevin J. Smith a * a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, 2360 East Mall, Vancouver, BC, V6T 1Z3, Canada Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering University of British Columbia 2360 East Mall Vancouver BC V6T 1Z3 Canada 1Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of British Columbia, 2360 East Mall, Vancouver, B.C., V6T 1Z3, Canada. b Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Room 353B Lower Mall Research Station, 2259 Lower Mall, Vancouver, BC, V6T1Z4, Canada Korea Institute of Science and Technology Room 353B Lower Mall Research Station, 2259 Lower Mall Vancouver BC V6T1Z4 Canada 2Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Room 353B Lower Mall Research Station, 2259 Lower Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T1Z4 ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The stability of Mo2C/carbon catalysts was assessed for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of dibenzofuran (DBF) at realistic operating conditions. Catalyst stability was determined by the degree of oxidation of the Mo2C, which in turn was determined by the Mo2C properties and the reaction conditions. Decreased Mo loading resulted in smaller Mo2C particles and faster oxidation. Increased concentration of DBF and reduced H2 pressure (4.1–2.1 MPa) increased Mo2C oxidation. The dynamic oxidation of Mo2C during HDO depended on the oxidation history of the catalyst. Oxidation of the Mo2C reduced hydrogenation activity and increased selectivity to direct deoxygenation (DDO) products. DFT analysis showed that small amounts of O did not change the preferred surface adsorption geometry of DBF on Mo2C (101). H2 dissociative adsorption was not weakened either. At 350 °C and low concentration of DBF (0.2 wt.%), the 2%Mo2C/APC catalyst was stable for >10 h. Keywords Molybdenum carbide Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) Catalyst stability Carbothermal hydrogen reduction Dibenzofuran Density functional theory 1 Introduction Bio-fuels derived from renewable resources are potential alternatives to fossil fuels [1,2]. Fast pyrolysis converts biomass into liquid (65−70  wt.%), gas (10−20  wt.%) and solid (15−20  wt.%) products at moderate conditions (ca. 500 °C, residence time: ≤2 s, in the absence of air). The obtained liquid bio-oil has a high-O content (40−50  wt.%) and poor stability that prevents its direct use as a fuel [3–5]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is used to improve the quality of the bio-oil by catalytic O removal in the presence of H2 at elevated temperatures (200–400 °C) [6–8]. The HDO of bio-oils occurs by catalytic hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions. Hence the catalyst must have the ability to dissociate H2 while also activating C-O, C-C and C=C bonds. Many catalysts have been reported for HDO, including Ni(Co)-MoS/γ-Al2O3 [9–12] and noble metals [13,14]. Although Ni(Co)MoS/γ-Al2O3 is effective, deactivation in the presence of O (and no S) is significant whereas the high cost of noble metals limits their use. Lower cost transition metal carbides, with catalytic behaviour similar to that of some noble metals, have been studied for hydrodesulphurization (HDS) and hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) [15,16]. More recently they have also been explored for the HDO of oxygenated compounds [17–22]. In a comparative study of 2-methoxyphenol HDO at realistic operating conditions (3.4 MPa and 240−375 °C) on Mo2C, Ru and Pd catalysts, Mo2C was most effective for direct O removal with minimal hydrogenation [17]. Jongerius et al. [18] and Engelhardt et al. [23] also reported that direct deoxygenation (DDO) was dominant on Mo2C and attributed this behaviour to O modification of the Mo2C. The presence of O means that the carbide structure is usually presented as a mixture of Mo2C and MoOxCy, leading to the co-existence of metallic and acidic functionalities [19,20]. As reported by Bhan et al. [19,24,25], the catalyst functionality can be tuned by adjusting the O content of the carbide (the ratio of Mo2C/MoOxCy) through catalyst synthesis or reaction conditions. The higher hydrogenation activity of phase pure Mo2C (versus Mo2C/MoOxCy) has been reported by several researchers [26,27]. HDO on oxophilic Mo2C results in surface adsorption or incorporation of O to produce Mo oxycarbides [28,29]. Lee et al. reported that the introduction of O to Mo2C at a O/Mo molar ratio of 0.075 resulted in a 3-fold reduction in the rate of benzene generation during the HDO of anisole, with a corresponding reduction in the number of active sites of the catalyst [30]. The O also decreased the anisole hydrogenation (HYD) rate [31]. Moreover, the O-modified Mo2C is known to possess acidic sites, as reported by Sullivan et al. [32], in which O2 introduced as co-feed, resulted in a 30-fold increase in the acidity of the Mo2C. These authors concluded that the oxidised Mo2C was more selective to the direct deoxygenation of anisole (DDO route) [33]. The effect of different O sources (CO2, H2O and O2) on Mo2C has also been reported for the vapor phase HDO of m-cresol [34]. The results indicated that the TOF for toluene formation was independent of the O source. Also note that incomplete carburization of the MoOx precursor during carbide synthesis can result in O on the surface and/or in the bulk structure, which may also inhibit Mo2C activity, especially for hydrogenation [26]. Although changes to the Mo2C catalyst surface during reaction have been noted in several studies [19,24,34,35], the impact of reaction conditions on the catalyst properties and corresponding stability and activity, especially at the high temperatures and pressures relevant to bio-oil HDO, have not been reported. In the present work, the stability of Mo2C supported on activated petroleum coke (APC) with various particle sizes was examined for the HDO of dibenzofuran (DBF) at varying operating conditions (temperature, pressure and O content of the feed). The data were collected continuously to capture changes in the catalyst performance with time-on-stream (TOS) at each set of operating conditions. The impact of the oxidation history of the catalyst was assessed by subsequently monitoring the DBF conversion and product selectivity at a standard set of operating conditions. The study was done at relatively high temperatures (330–370 °C) and H2 pressures (4.1, 3.1 and 2.1 MPa) to mimic realistic HDO reaction conditions and complement the data of Chen et al. [36], in which the HDO of mixtures of phenolic compounds on Mo2C was reported at ambient pressure and mild reaction temperatures (260−280 °C). The impact of oxygen on the Mo2C catalyst was investigated using several characterization methods, combined with DFT analysis of DBF adsorption and H2 dissociative adsorption on both clean and O-modified Mo2C surfaces. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization An activated petroleum coke (APC), derived from a Canadian oilsands delayed coker, was used as the catalyst support. The activation procedure for the petroleum coke has been reported previously [37]. The APC was wet impregnated using solutions of ammonium heptamolybdate (AHM) to yield Mo loadings of 2–10 wt.%. Mo2C was subsequently generated by carbothermal hydrogen reduction (CHR) of the AHM/APC precursor, as described previously [38]. Finally, the catalyst was passivated in a 1 vol% O2/N2 gas flow at a rate of 20 m L(STP)/min and room temperature for 2 h. The acquired catalysts were designated as xxMo2C/APC, where xx represents the Mo loading (wt.%). The textural properties of both the fresh and used catalysts, including surface area and pore volume, were determined by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer at −196 °C. The 2D-NLDFT-HS method was used for surface area calculation from adsorption data collected at P/Po values of 0.01−0.30. The total pore volume was defined as the sum of mesopore (2−50 nm) and micropore volume (≤2 nm). Similarly, the NLDFT method was applied to calculate the pore volume. CO uptake by the fresh and used Mo2C/APC catalysts was measured using a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the fresh, passivated catalysts, a H2 reduction was performed at 400 °C for 2 h to remove the passivation layer prior to the CO uptake measurement. This pre-treatment was consistent with that used prior to the catalyst activity assessment for the HDO of dibenzofuran (DBF). Following the reaction test, the used catalysts were treated in H2 at 70 °C for 90 min prior to a CO uptake measurement, to ensure removal of O adsorbed during handling of the used catalyst. Following the pre-treatment, the CO uptake was initiated by pulsing 0.5 mL of CO into a 50 m L(STP)/min He flow at 60 °C. The injection was repeated until there was no further change in the CO uptake signal. The number of Mo active sites was estimated assuming one CO molecule titrates one active site. The acidic properties of the Mo2C/APC catalysts were determined by NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) using the same Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 unit. The catalyst was firstly purged in He flow at 100 °C for 60 min, followed by exposure to a 40 mL(STP)/min flow of 15 mol% NH3/He at 70 °C for 60 min to chemisorb the NH3. The catalyst sample was then flushed in a He flow at 100 °C for 2 h to remove weakly adsorbed NH3. Finally, the sample was heated from 100 to 550 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min in the same He flow, holding for 30 min at the final temperature, while measuring the amount of NH3 desorbed using the TCD. Similarly, H2-TPD was used to determine the H2 adsorption on the Mo2C/APC catalysts. A 9.5 mol% H2/Ar gas mixture was used as the treatment gas, followed by an Ar flush (40 mL(STP)/min) at 70 °C, holding for 90 min, to remove physisorbed H2. Finally, the sample was heated from 70 to 400 °C at 10 °C/min, maintaining the final temperature for 30 min. The NH3 and H2 uptakes are reported as the moles of NH3 or H2 adsorbed per gram of Mo contained in the catalyst. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Leybold Max200) was used for detection of the surface chemical properties of both the fresh and used catalysts. The XPS was operated with a Mg Kα photon source generated at 1253.6 eV. The pass energy was 192 eV for survey scan analysis and 48 eV for the narrow scan. To minimize O contamination during sample transfer to the XPS unit, fresh catalysts were transferred directly from the U-tube reactor used in their preparation to a N2 glove bag without air exposure, while the used catalysts recovered from the reactor were stored in a sealed vial. Prior to transfer to the XPS unit they were reduced in H2 at 400 °C for 2 h before also being transferred to the glove bag. Exposure of the samples to the atmosphere during transfer from the glove bag to the XPS unit was minimized to less than 2 min. All spectra were analyzed by XPSPEAK41 software after Shirley background correction. The particle size distribution of both the fresh and used 2Mo2C/APC catalysts was calculated by collecting >50 particles/clusters from several TEM images, as measured by a FEI Tecnai Osiris at 200 kV, with a resolution limit of 0.14 nm. A lognormal distribution was applied to the measured data and used to estimate an average particle size. 2.2 Catalytic performance measurement in HDO of dibenzofuran (DBF) The performance of the catalysts was assessed in a packed bed reactor (Length: 50 cm; hot zone: 30 cm; ID: 8.64 mm; catalyst bed volume: 2.5 mL) using 0.2 or 2  wt.% DBF in decalin as feed (O concentration: 10.6 or 106 mmol/Ldecalin). Prior to the reaction, the passivation layer of the Mo2C/APC catalyst was removed by H2 reduction at 400 °C for 2 h. The HDO reactions were conducted at 310, 330, 350 and 370 °C and H2 pressures of 2.1, 3.1 or 4.1 MPa and a H2/feed volumetric ratio of 600. The liquid feed was pumped into the reactor at a liquid-hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 4 h−1 before vaporizing in the reactor. The liquid products, collected periodically from a downstream condenser, were analyzed by GC-MS (Shimadzu (QP-2010-S) GC/MS and RTX5 30 m × 0.25 mm capillary column) based on an external calibration method with an R2 ≥ 99% for the calibration curves. Products were grouped into four categories based on species detected by GC-MS, as shown in Fig. 1 : (1) DDO products: biphenyl (BPh); (2) O-containing products: tetrahydrodibenzofuran (THDBF) and 2-cyclohexylphenol (2-CHP); (3) HYD products: cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) and bicyclohexyl (BCH); (4) cracked products: benzene and cyclohexane. The overall carbon balance between feed and effluent was ≥95% for all activity data reported herein and experimental repeatability was estimated to be within ±95%. The stability of the catalysts was assessed by monitoring the DBF conversion and product selectivity at one set of operating conditions with time-on-stream. In addition, several experiments were conducted in two sequential stages. In Stage I, the catalyst was operated at a set of operating conditions for a period of about 8 h. Stage II followed immediately, but at a standard set of operating conditions (350 °C, LHSV = 4 h−1 and 0.2  wt.% DBF). By continuously monitoring the DBF conversion and product selectivity in Stage II, the impact of the process conditions of Stage I on the catalyst activity and stability could be determined. In one set of experiments, a regeneration in H2 at 400 °C was done prior to the start of Stage II (as indicated in Fig. 2 d). The reactant conversion and relevant product selectivities were calculated as follows: (1) D B F c o n v e r s i o n , % = 100 × ∑ y i y D B F o (2) H D O c o n v e r s i o n , % = 100 × ∑ y i - ∑ y o i y D B F o (3) P r o d u c t i s e l e c t i v i t y , % = 100 × y i ∑ y i where, yi represents the mole fraction of product i in the product stream; y D B F o is the initial molar fraction of DBF in the feed; y o i is the molar fraction of O-containing product i. 2.3 Computational model and methods An eclipsed configuration of bulk β-Mo2C was applied in this study, details of which have been reported previously [38]. The Mo2C (101) surface was selected for the study since it is the most stable plane at the synthesized temperature [39] and is the most abundant plane observed through TEM. The Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [40,41] using the plane-wave based periodic method was applied to conduct DFT calculations. The projector-augmented wave (PAW) method combined with generalized gradient approximation with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) was used to describe the electron-ion interaction and the electron exchange correlation energy. Van der Waal’s dDsC dispersion correction was also applied in the case of DBF adsorption. A cut-off energy of 400 eV was used in all calculations with a total convergence of >10−4. In all calculations, the adsorbed molecules on the topmost layer were relaxed to their optimized positions. A 5 × 5 × 5 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid for sampling the Brillouin zone was used for bulk optimization. A 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid set was applied for supercell optimization. The Climbing Image Nudged Elastic Band (CINEB) method was used for searching of the transition state. The adsorption energy Eads was calculated by the following equation: (4) Eads= E(X/slab) – EX – E(slab) where E(X/slab) represents the energy of species X adsorbed on slab, EX represents the energy of species X, and E(slab) represents the energy of the slab. The energy barrier (Ea) and reaction energy (Er) were calculated by the following equations: (5) Ea= ETS – EIS (6) Er= EFS – EIS where EIS, ETS, and EFS represent the energies of the initial state, transition state and final state of H2 adsorbed on the slab, respectively. The Gibbs free energy of adsorption (ΔGAds) was calculated by the following equation [42]: (7) Δ G A d s ( T , P ) = E a d s - 3 k T + Δ Z P E - k T ln 1 Z D B F r o t T * Z D B F t r a n s T , P - k T l n ( P P 0 ) Further details are provided in [38]. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization The textural properties of the Mo2C/APC catalysts, reported in Table 1 , show that the surface area and micropore volume of the fresh catalysts decreased marginally with increased Mo loading, while the mesopore volume was highest at a Mo loading of 10  wt.% [43]. In addition, there was a corresponding increase in Mo2C particle size, as measured by TEM, with increased Mo2C loading. These data indicate that as the Mo loading (and Mo2C particle size) increased, some of the micropores were blocked leading to a decrease in surface area and micropore volume. The loss in surface area and pore volume of the 2Mo2C/APC catalysts after reaction was dependent on both the reaction temperature and the H2 pressure (Table 1). As the H2 pressure decreased from 4.1–2.1 MPa, there was an increased loss in surface area and micropore volume, without a significant change in the catalyst mesopore volume, while the Mo2C particle size doubled (Table 1 and Fig. S1). These results are consistent with a micropore volume blocking mechanism associated with the Mo2C particle growth. However, at a reaction temperature of 370 °C there was a significant loss in both meso- and micropore volume, and a significant loss in surface area, suggesting that at this temperature, both sintering and coking of the Mo2C catalyst likely occurred. The CO uptake data of Table 2 , reported per gram of Mo, show a reduction with increased Mo2C loading, indicative of a reduced Mo2C dispersion, confirming the corresponding increase in Mo2C particle size determined by TEM (Table 1). A much more significant 10-fold reduction in CO uptake occurred after reaction of the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst (Table 2) that cannot be due to Mo2C particle growth alone. Rather, a loss in active sites through partial oxidation or coking must have also occurred. H2 regeneration of the used catalyst at 400 °C increased the CO uptake, but it remained well below that of the fresh catalysts, indicating that modification of the Mo2C during HDO was irreversible. Note that the CO uptake of the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst after reaction at 330 °C was lower than that after reaction at 350 °C, indicating that more active sites were lost at lower reaction temperature (330 °C) where less particle growth occurred. Hence we conclude that the loss in active sites as measured by CO uptake was mostly due to oxidation. The NH3-TPD and H2-TPD results of the fresh and used Mo2C/APC catalysts with different Mo loading are also summarized in Table 2 and Fig. S2. Two NH3 desorption peaks were observed, as shown in Figure S2 (a) and (c), characterized by low (< 400 °C) and high (> 400 °C) temperature and assigned to weak and strong acid sites, respectively. The NH3 desorption peak at lower temperature is ascribed to Mo2C species [44–46]; whereas the high temperature peak is assigned to MoOxCy or O-modified Mo2C species [47]. Similar observations were reported by Iglesia et al. on O-modified tungsten carbides [48–50]. Note that for the fresh catalysts, the total amount of NH3 desorbed decreased with increased Mo2C loading (Table 2) and the fresh 2Mo2C/APC with higher Mo2C dispersion had more NH3 desorbed per gram of Mo at higher temperature (>400 °C), indicating a stronger acidity compared to the 5Mo2C/APC and the 10Mo2C/APC catalysts. As Mo loading increased, the amount of NH3 desorbed at higher T decreased, while it increased at lower T (< 400 °C). The data also show that there was a >2-fold increase in NH3 desorbed at higher T after reaction, indicative of further oxidation of the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst during reaction. The H2-TPD measurement was used to determine the concentration of H adsorption sites [51]. The peak maximum for lower temperature H2-desorption was in the range of 150−280 °C, while a higher temperature peak occurred at 350−400 °C. The peak maximum temperature decreased with decreased Mo2C loading, indicative of a weaker interaction between adsorbed H and Mo2C on smaller particles. The fresh 2Mo2C/APC catalyst had more H desorbed than 5Mo2C/APC and 10Mo2C/APC catalysts (Table 2). Note that H2-TPD measurements on the used catalysts resulted in high uptakes (not reported) because of reaction with O-species present on the carbon support. The XPS analysis of the fresh and used 2Mo2C/APC catalysts is summarized in Table 3 . The Mo 3d spectra were deconvoluted into three peaks assigned to Mo2+ (carbide), Mo4+ (oxycarbide), and Mo6+ (oxide), respectively as presented in Figure S3 [38], with binding energies (BEs) of 228.4, 229.8, and 232.4 eV, respectively and each with Mo 3d5/2 and Mo3d3/2 spin-orbital splitting of 3.1 eV and an area ratio of 3:2. Similarly, the O 1s was deconvoluted and assigned to Mo-O and C-O species (Figure S4). The data indicate that following reaction there was a significant loss in carbide content of the used 2Mo2C/APC catalyst (Table 3). Both the surface and bulk O/Mo ratio increased following reaction and the fraction of Mo4+ species decreased. The used catalyst data also show that as the H2 reaction pressure decreased, the loss in carbide species increased and the O bound to C decreased. 3.2 Catalyst activity and stability The effect of Mo2C particle size on the HDO of DBF at 350 °C, 4.1 MPa, LHSV of 4 h−1, with the same amount of Mo loaded in the catalyst bed (0.019 g Mo), is shown in Fig. 3 as a function of time-on-stream (TOS). The Mo2C/APC catalysts had 100% DBF conversion at the reaction conditions and no O-containing products were detected. However, the selectivity slowly changed with TOS. For the 2%Mo2C/APC catalyst, the HYD product selectivity (CHB and BCH) decreased from 55% to 38%; whereas, an increase in DDO product selectivity (BPh) was observed from 15% to 27% (Fig. 3 (a)). Note that the selectivity change with TOS occurred on all Mo2C/APC catalysts although the time period over which the change was observed varied with Mo2C loading (i.e. Mo2C particle size). For the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst, ca. 150 min was required to reach steady state, while for the 5Mo2C/APC and 10Mo2C/APC catalysts, 280 min and >400 min was required, respectively. Hence, larger particles were less prone to selectivity change, which we assume reflects a greater ability to resist oxidation. A similar phenomenon was reported by Stellwagen et al. [52], also noting improved resistance to oxidation of larger catalyst particles during HDO. Also, it is noteworthy that the selectivities of all catalysts trend toward the same value at long TOS (400–600 min), independent of Mo2C particle size, suggesting that an equilibrium O adsorption is achieved on the Mo2C surface for all particle sizes. The effect of reaction temperature and feed O content on the catalyst stability was investigated using the 2Mo2C/APC and 10Mo2C/APC catalysts, with the results presented in Fig. 2 and Table 4 . These experiments were conducted in two sequential stages, with the second stage (Stage II, Table 4) conducted at a standard set of operating conditions (350 °C and LHSV of 4 h−1 and 0.2  wt.% DBF in the feed; Experiment #1 of Table 4), used to assess the change in DBF conversion and product selectivity as a consequence of the reaction conditions of Stage I. Fig. 2(a) presents the DBF conversion and selectivity measured at 350 °C and LHSV of 4 h−1 over the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst with TOS, using a high O content feed (2.0  wt.% DBF; Experiment #3, Stage I in Table 4). After a period of 500 min the DBF concentration in the feed was reduced to 0.2  wt.% (Stage II). Note that there was no significant change in DBF conversion and product selectivity during the first 500 min of reaction, indicative of a rapid uptake of O on the small Mo2C particles in the presence of a high concentration of DBF. The stabilized DBF conversion in Stage II was about 37% and the product selectivity to cracked, DDO and HYD products was 34, 27, and 36%, respectively (Table 4). Following the reduction in the DBF feed concentration to 0.2  wt.%, the DBF conversion recovered to above 98% after >300 min and selectivity remained relatively stable with only minor changes, as shown in Fig. 3(a). The calculated 1st-order rate constants (ki) as reported in Table 4 (Experiment #3) were similar in Stage I (kI) and Stage II (kII). These results suggest that the activity and selectivity of the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst did not change significantly when processing a feed with a high O content at 350 °C. A similar measurement was made at lower temperature (330 °C) as reported in Fig. 2(b). As expected, a lower DBF conversion (∼3%) resulted at the lower temperature with the 2  wt.% DBF in the feed, but DBF conversion only increased to 25% when the reaction temperature increased to 350 °C and the DBF feed content was reduced to 0.2  wt.% (Stage II, Experiment #4, Table 4). The selectivity to cracked, DDO, HYD and O-containing products was 16, 35, 36 and 14%, respectively, significantly different to that obtained at the same reaction conditions of Fig. 3(a) and summarized as Experiment #1, Table 4. One possible reason for the reduced catalyst activity and change in selectivity is an irreversible O adsorption and oxidation of Mo2C that occurred at the lower temperature in the presence of a high concentration of DBF (2  wt.% DBF). At 370 °C with 2% DBF in the feed (Table 4, Exp 2) the catalyst activity was also unexpectedly low (compared to that measured at 350 °C; Exp 3, Stage I), although the HYD selectivity remained high (46%). This suggests additional loss of active sites by carbon deposition and particle growth at this temperature, while some oxidation also occurred. Similar stability tests were completed on the 10Mo2C/APC catalyst, as reported in Table 4, Fig. 2(c) and (d). No conversion or selectivity changes with TOS were captured at a high DBF feed concentration (2.0  wt.%) (Fig. 2 (c) Stage I). The DBF conversion of 10Mo2C/APC (ca. 29%) was slightly lower than that of the 2Mo2C/APC (ca. 37%; Fig. 2(a) Stage I), indicating smaller particles are more active due to a higher dispersion of Mo2C. Also, the selectivity of the 10Mo2C/APC catalyst at steady-state (as indicated by the Stage I of Fig. 2(c)) is different to that of the 2Mo2C/APC at the same reaction conditions (Fig. 3(c)). The selectivity to cracked, DDO, HYD and O-containing products was 20, 44, 34 and 3%, respectively, (Stage I, Experiment #6, Table 4) suggesting an increase in DDO and decrease in HYD product selectivity for larger Mo2C particles (10Mo2C/APC). However, in Stage II with the DBF in the feed reduced to 0.2  wt.% DBF and the same reaction temperature, the DBF conversion and product selectivity recover to the values observed for Experiment #5 (Table 4), meaning that with the higher loading Mo2C catalyst, stability was maintained. Moreover, the time required for the catalyst to again achieve steady-state following reduction of the DBF feed concentration was less than that observed for the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst. In Fig. 2(d), a lower temperature (310 °C) was used in Stage I of the stability test for the 10Mo2C/APC catalyst (Experiment 7, Table 4), resulting in ∼5% DBF conversion. The catalyst was then regenerated in H2 after the 500 min TOS before switching to Stage II at the same conditions as that used for Experiment #5. The catalyst regeneration conditions were the same as those used to remove the catalyst passivation layer (400 °C, 2 h) prior to reaction. After this regeneration process, the DBF conversion increased to 71% almost immediately with a significant change in selectivity, approaching that observed for Experiment #5. Hence, the oxidation of the Mo2C catalyst cannot be completely reversed simply by regeneration in H2, consistent with the used catalyst CO uptake data reported in Table 1. The effect of H2 pressure on the catalyst stability was also investigated, as reported in Fig. 4 and Table 5 . The DBF conversion and product selectivity over the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst at 350 °C, LHSV = 4 h−1 and DBF concentration of 0.2  wt.% in the feed was measured with TOS at H2 pressures of 2.1, 3.1 and 4.1 MPa. A clear decrease in DBF conversion was observed at lower pressures of 2.1 and 3.1 MPa. At 2.1 MPa, the decrease was observed at the start of the TOS period while at 3.1 MPa, there was a period of about 50 min with stable conversion prior to a significant drop (Fig. 4 (a) and (b)). The catalyst selectivities changed as well, with a decrease in HYD products and increase in DDO products. The stabilized selectivity was similar under these two conditions as were the catalyst activities, as measured by the 1st-order rate constants reported in Table 5. 3.3 DFT calculations Table 6 and Figs. S.5–S.8 compare the horizontal and vertical adsorption energies of DBF on a clean Mo2C (101) surface and the same surface with selected C atoms replaced by O atoms. Three different Mo2C (101) surfaces, identified as Mo2C-1RO, Mo2C-2RO, and Mo2C-3RO with 1, 2 and 3 C atoms replaced by O, respectively. All adsorption was assumed to occur on the same Mo site with O replacement around the Mo atom. Four different orientations of DBF adsorption were considered, two vertical and two horizontal, as shown in Figs. S.5–S.8. The DFT data show that replacement of one C atom with O enhanced both the horizontal and vertical adsorption of DBF on the (101) surface (the Gibbs free energy of adsorption became more negative). Further replacement of 2 or 3 C atoms with O on the same surface had less impact, except in the case of the horizontal adsorption shown as DBF-H1 (Figs. S.7 and S.8). Table 7 and Figure S.9 present the potential energy transition during dissociative adsorption of H2 on a clean Mo2C (101) surface and the same surface with one C atom replaced by O. The H2 dissociative adsorptions were on the same Mo site used for the DBF adsorption calculation. The replacement of O enhanced H2 dissociation marginally by lowering the energy barrier (Ea, Table 7) from 0.28 to 0.25 eV with 1 or 2 C atoms replaced with O; whereas, the barrier energy increased to 0.28 eV with 3 C atoms replaced by O. 4 Discussion The fact that O may be retained by the oxophilic Mo2C catalyst during HDO, modifying the structure of Mo2C and inhibiting HYD reactions, has been previously demonstrated [24]. Herein, we report on the effect of Mo2C loading and the severity of the HDO reaction conditions on the stability of Mo2C catalysts, highlighting the role that O plays in determining the catalyst stability. The properties of the fresh Mo2C/APC catalysts were impacted by the Mo2C loading, with CO and NH3 uptake decreasing with increased Mo2C loading, corresponding to an increase in Mo2C particle size (Tables 1 and 2). The Mo2C/APC catalyst acidity was mostly due to Mo species since the acidity of the APC support was low (< 10 μmol/g) [37]. The data of Tables 2, 3 and S1 show that both the acidity and surface O/Mo ratio decreased with increased Mo loading, consistent with previous studies showing that the acidity is closely related to the degree of surface oxidation of the Mo2C [45,53]. The stability of the Mo2C/APC catalysts during the HDO of DBF was dependent on the catalyst properties and the reaction conditions. The catalyst with lower Mo loading (2Mo2C/APC) had smaller Mo2C particles with more edge sites that are readily oxidised, compared to the higher Mo loading catalyst (10Mo2C/APC). Consequently, the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst stabilized more rapidly following introduction of the O-containing feedstock during HDO, compared to the 10Mo2C/APC catalyst (Fig. 3(a)). Partial oxidation of the Mo2C also meant that the HYD rate, favored on the carbide surface, decreased faster on the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst than the catalysts with higher loading (Table S2 and Fig. 3(d)). After stabilization, all 3 catalysts reached similar selectivity irrespective of loading. In previous work it was shown that the distribution of Mo species (carbide versus oxycarbide) following CHR synthesis was not dependent on Mo loading [38], suggesting that differences in catalyst stability reported herein arise mostly from the degree of oxidation of the Mo2C during reaction as determined by the Mo2C particle size and the reaction conditions. At 350 °C and LHSV = 4 h−1, the activity and selectivity of the 2Mo2C/APC catalyst obtained with 0.2  wt.% DBF in the feed (Table 4, Exp 1) remained unchanged (Table 4, Exp 3, Stage II) following a 10 h reaction period in a feed with 10×’s the O content (2.0  wt.% DBF). The calculated 1st order rate constant for DBF conversion was also the same for both Stage I and II (Table 4 Exp 3). However, when initially operated at temperatures above and below 350 °C (Table 4, Stage I of Exps 2 and 4), there was a significant loss in DBF conversion and change in product selectivity with increased DDO selectivity when measured at the standard set of conditions (Table 4, Exp 1 compared to Stage II of Exps 2–4). At the same time, the catalyst O/Mo surface ratio and acidity increased while the CO uptake decreased following use, indicative of significant O uptake by the catalyst. The catalyst stability data measured in the presence of reduced H2 pressure also indicate that catalyst oxidation has a significant impact on catalyst stability. Reduced H2 pressure decreases the dissociative adsorption of H2 on the catalyst surface but also reduces the likelihood of reduction of the partially oxidised Mo surface. Hence, as the H2 pressure decreased, the catalyst remained more oxidised, as shown by the XPS data of Table 3. Low H2 pressure resulted in more irreversible oxidation of the Mo2C catalyst and hence a significant drop in activity with increased DDO selectivity. In addition, the textural properties of the used catalyst indicate that at lower pressure, there was a more significant loss in surface area and pore volume. The loss was likely due to the growth of Mo species with increased oxidation (Table 1) and a possible increase in coke deposition. The above data demonstrate that the O content of the reaction environment, together with the O affinity of the catalyst, as determined by the catalyst properties, play an important role in determining the extent of Mo2C oxidation and hence, the catalyst stability. As shown in Fig. 3, all particle sizes had similar selectivity initially when the DBF concentration was low (0.2  wt.%). The DFT calculations indicate that adsorption of low amounts of O atoms on the Mo2C (101) surface does not significantly impact the adsorption of DBF and dissociation of H2 on the catalyst surface. Hence the O-modified Mo2C has the ability to hydrogenate the DBF when the feed DBF concentration is low. However, at high DBF concentrations and low temperatures, O adsorption is more significant, resulting in reduced DBF conversion and increased DDO selectivity. At high reaction temperatures (370 °C), high DBF conversion implies more O available for adsorption on the Mo2C. The results from this study show that there is a dynamic interaction between the Mo2C and the O which determines both the catalyst stability and the catalyst activity and selectivity. For example, at conditions of high severity (high temperature and high O content) the catalyst oxidation is more severe and is not reversible when reaction severity is subsequently reduced (Fig. 2 and Table 4). Hence the stability of these catalysts and the corresponding activity/selectivity observed at a particular set of operating conditions, depends on catalyst properties (Mo2C particle size), the oxidation state of the catalyst as determined by the dynamic response of the catalyst to the operating conditions and the operating history of the catalyst. In addition, the used catalyst textural data indicate significant loss in surface area and pore volume after reaction at high temperature (370 °C). As the H2 pressure decreased there was also an increased loss in micropore volume that is likely linked to the large increase in Mo2C particle size after use (Table 1). Similar phenomena were observed by Mortensen et al. [54] in their study of Mo2C catalysts during the HDO of phenol and 1-octanol. 5 Conclusion The effect of Mo2C oxidation on catalyst stability during HDO is reported. The study shows that reaction temperature, H2 pressure and O content of the feed determined the degree of Mo2C oxidation. Furthermore, smaller Mo2C particles were more easily oxidised than larger particles. Oxidation of the Mo2C resulted in reduced catalyst activity and increased selectivity to direct deoxygenation (DDO) products. The oxidation of Mo2C during HDO was not always reversible and depended on the oxidation history of the catalyst. Author contributions All authors contributed equally to this work. coredata.dc:description: The stability of Mo2C/carbon catalysts was assessed for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of dibenzofuran (DBF) at realistic operating conditions. Catalyst stability was determined by the degree of oxidation of the Mo2C, which in turn was determined by the Mo2C properties and the reaction conditions. Decreased Mo loading resulted in smaller Mo2C particles and faster oxidation. Increased concentration of DBF and reduced H2 pressure (4.1–2.1 MPa) increased Mo2C oxidation. The dynamic oxidation of Mo2C during HDO depended on the oxidation history of the catalyst. Oxidation of the Mo2C reduced hydrogenation activity and increased selectivity to direct deoxygenation (DDO) products. DFT analysis showed that small amounts of O did not change the preferred surface adsorption geometry of DBF on Mo2C (101). H2 dissociative adsorption was not weakened either. At 350 °C and low concentration of DBF (0.2 wt.%), the 2%Mo2C/APC catalyst was stable for >10 h.
coredata.dc:title: Stability of Mo2C/carbon catalysts during dibenzofuran hydrodeoxygenation
